003.comments: FNH 250 003 has been blocked from registration as there is a waitlist for this course. Please register onto the waitlist (FNH 250 0W3) if you wish to be considered for this course.

0W1.comments: This is a Wait List Section for FNH 250 Section 001. Students will be moved according to their priority on the waitlist if space becomes available. All queries should be directed to the Faculty of Land and Food Systems Student Services at students@landfood.ubc.ca.

0W3.comments: This is a Wait List Section for FNH 250 Section 003. Students with other forms of first-year BIOL credits (transfer or otherwise) should add themselves to the waitlist section.  Students will be moved according to their priority on the waitlist if space becomes available. All queries should be directed to the Faculty of Land and Food Systems Student Services at students@landfood.ubc.ca.

1W1.comments: This is a Wait List Section for FNH 250 Section 99A. Students will be moved according to their priority on the waitlist if space becomes available. All queries should be directed to the Faculty of Land and Food Systems Student Services at students@landfood.ubc.ca.

2W1.comments: This is a Wait List Section for FNH 250 Section 99C. Students will be moved according to their priority on the waitlist if space becomes available. All queries should be directed to the Faculty of Land and Food Systems Student Services at students@landfood.ubc.ca.

99A.comments: FNH 250 99A is currently blocked from registration - if you wish to be considered for this course, please register onto the waitlist FNH 250 1W1.This section of the course is ONLINE- distance education. All communication will be by email. It is your responsibility to ensure you have a valid email account so that you can be contacted with important information and updates. You can update your contact information through the Student Service Centre.Login to the course through canvas.ubc.ca   Students who are new to Canvas will want to check out a UBC Students Guide to CanvasFor more information including resources for distance learners visit distancelearning.ubc.ca

description: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
